repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Supersedes #3323

Fixes #1159.

This should be a simpler way of dealing with the long-standing generator and comprehension scoping issues. Unlike the previous PR it is fairly non-intrusive (i.e. doesn't wrap everything in `ResultRefNodes`) and therefore the changes should be more reasonable. Instead it:

1. Gives `IteratorNode` a scope (pointed at the outer scope rather than the scope of the generator/comprehension)
2. Tags each `ExprNode` inside the generator iterator sequence with a number, and uses those tags later to work out what needs to be converted to an argument for the generator. If an `ExprNode` is optimized out then that's fine - one of its children will have been tagged.

What remains to be done is:
1. Copying across the remaining (useful) tests from #3323
2. Fixing all the bugs that the test-suite is about to reveal...

therefore this is draft for now. But hopefully not for too long...

comment_data.body: `int or None` is no longer quite true and I need to come back and fix that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -312,6 +312,8 @@ class ExprNode(Node):
     #  is_numpy_attribute   boolean   Is a Numpy module attribute
     #                            result_code/temp_result can safely be set to None
     #  annotation   ExprNode or None    PEP526 annotation for names or expressions
+    #  generator_arg_tag  int or None   A tag to mark ExprNodes that potentially need to

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        # For generator expression targets, the rhs can have a different scope than the lhs.
        self.rhs_scope = rhs_scope
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -324,16 +324,18 @@ def __init__(self, lhs, rhs, entry):
         self.is_arg = False
         self.is_deletion = False
         self.inferred_type = None
+        self.rhs_scope = rhs_scope  # for generator expression targets, the rhs can have a different scope
+                                    # to the lhs

comment_data.body:
Are we sure that the loop or its iterator haven't been replaced at this point, by some preceding transform? I always find it a bit risky to make assumptions like this about the deep structure of nodes in the tree structure. Could this be set in a more local place, or by the inside node itself? Reaching out seems easier/safer than reaching in.

Also, you seem to be doing the same in `IteratorNode.analyse_declarations()`. Is that the case and intended?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9863,13 +9878,17 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.def_node.is_cyfunction = False
         # Force genexpr signature
         self.def_node.entry.signature = TypeSlots.pyfunction_noargs
+        self.loop.iterator.outer_scope = env

comment_data.body: Hmm. A stack has the advantage that things get cleaned up along the way. Here, the dict grows seems unbounded. Not sure if it matters, but it may make a difference.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -704,8 +706,8 @@ def visit_FuncDefNode(self, node):
         self.visitchildren(node, ('decorators',))
         self.env_stack.append(self.env)
         self.env = node.local_scope
-        self.stack.append(self.flow)
         self.flow = ControlFlow()
+        self.flows[self.env] = self.flow

comment_data.body: This makes it feel a bit like `ScopedExprNode`. The latter does more if you set `.has_local_scope`, but without that, if you set an explicit scope from outside, it might do what you want here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2710,10 +2713,13 @@ class IteratorNode(ExprNode):
     counter_cname = None
     reversed = False      # currently only used for list/tuple types (see Optimize.py)
     is_async = False
+    outer_scope = None    # non-None if sequence should be evaluated in a different scope

comment_data.body: Seeing this actually makes it seem weird that a `GeneratorExpressionNode` inherits from `LambdaNode`. It may not be outright wrong, but the first calls the function in order to create it. That's quite different. And it's what makes the difference here stick out.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9850,10 +9857,18 @@ class GeneratorExpressionNode(LambdaNode):
     #
     # loop      ForStatNode   the for-loop, containing a YieldExprNode
     # def_node  DefNode       the underlying generator 'def' node
+    # call_parameters [ExprNode]   (Internal) parameters passed to the DefNode call

comment_data.body:
You're using `or` everywhere else.
```suggestion
        return self.sequence.type_dependencies(self.outer_scope or env)
```
This part seems pretty generic to `ScopedExprNode`, at least from a quick look.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -759,7 +761,20 @@ def visit_GeneratorBodyDefNode(self, node):
     def visit_CTypeDefNode(self, node):
         return node
 
-    def mark_assignment(self, lhs, rhs=None):
+    def visit_IteratorNode(self, node):

comment_data.body:
I wonder if there can be more than one argument. In generator expressions, only the outermost iterable is special.
Are you anticipating optimisations for `zip()` or something like that?
If we can stick to one argument, that seems simpler (and gives us a standard `METH_O` signature, I think, right?).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9850,10 +9857,18 @@ class GeneratorExpressionNode(LambdaNode):
     #
     # loop      ForStatNode   the for-loop, containing a YieldExprNode
     # def_node  DefNode       the underlying generator 'def' node
+    # call_parameters [ExprNode]   (Internal) parameters passed to the DefNode call

comment_data.body: Hmm. Does this need a separate transform? Isn't the outermost iterable special enough to find it without deep traversal?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1404,6 +1404,127 @@ def visit_ExprNode(self, node):
         return node
 
 
+class _GeneratorExpressionArgumentsMarker(TreeVisitor, SkipDeclarations):
+    def __init__(self, gen_expr):
+        super(_GeneratorExpressionArgumentsMarker, self).__init__()
+        self.gen_expr = gen_expr
+        self.tag = 0
+
+    def visit_ExprNode(self, node):
+        if not node.is_literal:
+            # Don't bother tagging literal nodes
+            assert (not node.generator_arg_tag)  # nobody has tagged this first
+            node.generator_arg_tag = (self.tag, self.gen_expr)
+            self.tag +=1
+        self.visitchildren(node)
+
+    def visit_Node(self, node):
+        return  # we're only interested in the expressions that make up the iterator sequence
+                # so don't go beyond ExprNodes (e.g. into ForFromStatNode)
+
+    def visit_GeneratorExpressionNode(self, node):
+        node.generator_arg_tag = (self.tag, self.gen_expr)
+        self.tag += 1
+        # don't visit children, can't handle overlapping tags
+        # (and assume generator expressions don't end up optimized out in a way
+        #  that would require overlapping tags)
+
+
+class MarkGeneratorExpressionArguments(VisitorTransform, SkipDeclarations):
+    def visit_GeneratorExpressionNode(self, node):
+        self.visitchildren(node)
+        if not isinstance(node.loop, Nodes.ForInStatNode):
+            # Possibly should handle ForFromStatNode
+            # but for now do nothing
+            return node
+        itseq = node.loop.iterator.sequence
+        # literals do not need replacing with an argument
+        if itseq.is_literal:
+            return node
+        _GeneratorExpressionArgumentsMarker(node).visit(itseq)
+        return node
+
+    visit_Node = VisitorTransform.recurse_to_children
+
+
+class HandleGeneratorArguments(VisitorTransform, SkipDeclarations):

comment_data.body:
> I wonder if there can be more than one argument. 

Yes - quite frequently. Say:

```
return (x for x in range(func1(), func2()))
```

You should probably end up with arguments for `result_of_func1` and `result_of_func2` due to the optimizations. Obviously it'd be fairly easy to block the optimization and up up with one argument, but I got the impression that this wasn't popular!

>  If we can stick to one argument, that seems simpler (and gives us a standard METH_O signature, I think, right?).

It's called as a C function rather than a Python function so I don't think keeping the signature is hugely important.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9850,10 +9857,18 @@ class GeneratorExpressionNode(LambdaNode):
     #
     # loop      ForStatNode   the for-loop, containing a YieldExprNode
     # def_node  DefNode       the underlying generator 'def' node
+    # call_parameters [ExprNode]   (Internal) parameters passed to the DefNode call

comment_data.body:
> Are we sure that the loop or its iterator haven't been replaced at this point, by some preceding transform?

Fairly sure but some more guards to check the assumption might help.

> Could this be set in a more local place, or by the inside node itself? Reaching out seems easier/safer than reaching in.

I'll have a look. I think it's wrapped in quite a dew layers of `GeneratorBodyDefNodes` and similar, so the information about the scope isn't easily available there.

> Also, you seem to be doing the same in `IteratorNode.analyse_declarations()`. Is that the case and intended?

It's in `ComprehensionNode.analyse_declarations` which is intended (for very similar reasons).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9863,13 +9878,17 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         self.def_node.is_cyfunction = False
         # Force genexpr signature
         self.def_node.entry.signature = TypeSlots.pyfunction_noargs
+        self.loop.iterator.outer_scope = env

comment_data.body: Fair point. I'll see if it's possible to clean it up as I go (intuitively it seems like it should be...) and maybe use a tuple-pair stack instead of a dictionary.

-        self.stack.append(self.flow)

comment_data.body:
Just to highlight - this line has been modified.

Otherwise `ScopedExprNode` has been moved upwards in the file without changes
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2698,7 +2701,98 @@ def generate_result_code(self, code):
         self.generate_gotref(code)
 
 
-class IteratorNode(ExprNode):
+class ScopedExprNode(ExprNode):
+    # Abstract base class for ExprNodes that have their own local
+    # scope, such as generator expressions.
+    #
+    # expr_scope    Scope  the inner scope of the expression
+
+    subexprs = []
+    expr_scope = None
+
+    # does this node really have a local scope, e.g. does it leak loop
+    # variables or not?  non-leaking Py3 behaviour is default, except
+    # for list comprehensions where the behaviour differs in Py2 and
+    # Py3 (set in Parsing.py based on parser context)
+    has_local_scope = True
+
+    def init_scope(self, outer_scope, expr_scope=None):
+        if expr_scope is not None:
+            self.expr_scope = expr_scope
+        elif self.has_local_scope:
+            self.expr_scope = Symtab.ComprehensionScope(outer_scope)
+        elif not self.expr_scope:  # don't unset if it's already been set

comment_data.body:
> Could this be set in a more local place, or by the inside node itself?

~I've now done this. It needed a few additional tags on the scopes so that it could identify the right scope to use, but I think it's probably an improvement.~

Undone - doing it in a more local place ends up with the wrong answer when using nested loops and I don't see an easy way around it
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         # Force genexpr signature

+        self.loop.iterator.outer_scope = env

Sorts out scoping

But doesn't yet build compilable code

commit.message:
Rename GeneratorExpressionScope->ComprehensionScope

I think this is a remenant of an earlier implementation, but as
far as I can tell generator expressions *never* use
GeneratorExpressionScope and in fact it's only used for
comprehensions. This renaming is just to avoid some very
confusing variable naming in #4254

Make IteratorNode a ScopedExprNode

based on comments from review
Fixed bugs from CI/applied to async for loops
Handle genexpr as the sequence of another genexpr

title: Generator expression and comprehension scope
